subject: Cooking
title: Roman Garum: The Ancient Ketchup
description: A micro-lesson that makes Roman Garum: The Ancient Ketchup usable.

hook.text: Romans poured a fermented fish sauce on almost everything they ate. They called it garum.

buildup.text: Fish guts and salt were left to ferment in the sun for months until they liquefied into an amber sauce.

discovery.text: Garum was pure umami â€” packed with glutamates, just like modern fish sauce or soy sauce.

twist.text: The finest garum cost more than perfume. Factories in Spain exported it across the entire empire.

climax.text: When Rome fell, garum vanished from Europe â€” but survived in Asia as fish sauce and soy sauce.

punchline.text: Ketchup changes. The craving for umami never does.
